transcript: SPR_COMBO[es]Estamos en verano y mientras que algunas mujeres solo desean escapar a destinos tropicales, otras según TikTok, no tiene incluido "apperol spritz" y "amigas" en sus must de la temporada. En cambio, piensan en silencio, escritura sagrada y autorreflexión. El interés por el #MonkMode está en auge en Estados Unidos, y los conventos y monasterios se están llenando de mujeres que, siguiendo el ejemplo de Piper Ratliff de White Lotus , están reservando retiros espirituales. Originalmente, el #MonkMode tenía su lugar en la manosfera, donde los hombres recurrían a principios monásticos de abstinencia como forma de superación personal. Pero ahora, las chicas también están participando. La usuaria de TikTok MC, quien ha ganado seguidores documentando sus “side quests”, fue mencionada por Bustle al declarar que su monasterio católico favorito en el norte del estado de Nueva York ya estaba completamente reservado para la temporada. Usualmente, “solo le mandas un correo a las monjas”, pero este año tuvo que entrar a lista de espera. Monk Mode: la nueva tendencia de TikTok para las chicas este verano (TikTok) Históricamente, los monasterios y conventos han servido como escenarios de metáforas aterradoras sobre el patriarcado en películas de terror. En 2024, Sydney Sweeney interpretó a la hermana Cecilia, una joven monja estadounidense que se une a un convento remoto en Italia en la película Immaculate. Ese mismo año, The First Omen mostró a mujeres tomando los hábitos con consecuencias igual de escalofriantes. Te explicamos qué es #MonkMode (Neon/Shutterstock/Neon/Shutterstock) Pero en 2025, estos espacios están siendo tratados como centros de bienestar. En TikTok, las mujeres están trazando una línea —o mejor dicho, construyendo un castillo amurallado— entre ellas y las exigencias de la vida diaria, al tomar retiros silenciosos en conventos y monasterios. Y no se trata solo de buscar espacios libres de hombres (MC aclaró que está “enamorada” y tiene novio, pero “cuando el monasterio llama, simplemente tienes que responder”). Publicaciones como The Cut y Bustle sugieren que las mujeres se sienten atraídas por todo, desde la idea de una vida más comunitaria hasta la oportunidad de reducir el tiempo frente a las pantallas o encontrar inspiración para la decoración de interiores. Hay un tipo de minimalismo extremo, al estilo Marie Kondo , en algunas de las estancias monásticas que aparecen en TikTok. Levantarse muros de ladrillos dobles entre una y el mundo exterior con la esperanza de encontrar paz interior tiene sentido, considerando que hoy en día hay demasiadas formas de ser contactadas. Las apps en nuestros teléfonos, desde Rappi, Justo hasta Uber Eats, nos mandan notificaciones push constantemente, y nuestros DMs son un enjambre de actividad. Entrar en un espacio donde mirar el celular se considera casi una ofensa espiritual parece ser nuestra mejor opción para lograr un retiro tecnológicamente silencioso. Sin embargo, este auge de lo monástico no solo ha sido evidente en nuestras redes sociales y agendas de viaje. También ha llegado a las pasarelas y a nuestros clósets. Algunas de las tendencias más importantes del año incluyen el Castlecore (predicho por Pinterest), junto con el medieval core (y su versión Medieval Y2K Core, inspirada en Ella Enchanted). Como señaló Vogue, marcas como Zoe Gustavi, Christopher Esber, Fendi, Ulla Johnson y Alberta Ferretti hicieron referencias al claustro en sus colecciones otoño/invierno, mientras que Burberry fue más allá y envió a un caballero medieval directo a la pasarela. Más allá de las pasarelas internacionales, marcas independientes como la australiana Catholic Guilt —que vistió a Julia Fox en su reciente visita a Australia— y J'adorable están conquistando la escena nocturna. Dado el clima político actual, en el que los individuos más corruptos de nuestra sociedad parecen tener el mayor poder y visibilidad, la idea de una especie de guerra espiritual y un retiro hacia el ascetismo (lejos de todo lo relacionado con la boda de Bezos y Sánchez) tiene bastante sentido. Este artículo fue publicado por primera vez en ELLE AUS .

transcript: Transport for London (TfL) is offering a new partnership to an organisation or company willing to pay to sponsor the Waterloo & City line. The line – which runs on weekdays between Bank and Waterloo Underground stations – was opened in July 1898 and is colloquially known as The Drain. The two-stop, three-minute shuttle service is one of only two Tube lines that runs completely underground, the other being the Victoria line. On a post on professional networking site LinkedIn, TfL said the sponsorship offer "goes far beyond a typical media opportunity", although previous temporary brand "takeovers" of Tube stations have sparked complaints. TfL said: "It's full-line branding, from moquette seat fabric and signage to maps and experiential spaces, all right in the heart of London's business district." Moquette fabric is the durable, woollen seating material that is used in upholstery on Tube carriage seats, while an experiential space is described by TfL as a "pop-up presence for sampling and distribution in a pre-approved station space". TfL said: "Millions of professionals and decision-makers travel this route every year. Now, your brand can own the journey." Previous money-making marketing schemes on London Underground have created controversy. In 2018, Southgate Tube station was rebranded Gareth Southgate station for 48 hours, after the England men's football squad he managed finished fourth in the World Cup. In 2023, Bond Street was briefly renamed Burberry Street by the fashion brand to mark London Fashion, which raised £200,000 for the transport company. That led to more than 50 complaints to TfL with some passengers confused by the new temporary signage. Transport for All, a transport advocacy group led by disabled people, warned last year that "thoughtless PR stunts being used to plug holes in TfL funding cannot be at the expense of accessibility and safety for disabled passengers". The group also said that "messing around with station names... stops many disabled people being able to travel confidently". TfL documents state that brand sponsorship on its network can cost up to £7.5m. IFS Cloud's sponsorship of the cable car that links North Greenwich and Custom House in east London is worth £2.1m. While brands have previously "taken over" one or more Underground stations for several days, if successful this initiative would be the first time an entire Tube line would get a sponsor, albeit one with just two stations. The BBC formed a partnership with TfL in January 2022, rebranding Green Park station for 48 hours as Green Planet to promote Sir David Attenborough's five-part series.

TfL said: "It's full-line branding, from moquette seat fabric and signage to maps and experiential spaces, all right in the heart of London's business district." Moquette fabric is the durable, woollen seating material that is used in upholstery on Tube carriage seats, while an experiential space is described by TfL as a "pop-up presence for sampling and distribution in a pre-approved station space". TfL said: "Millions of professionals and decision-makers travel this route every year. Now, your brand can own the journey." Previous money-making marketing schemes on London Underground have created controversy. Bond Street was renamed Burberry Street in 2023, making TfL £200,000 [BBC] Southgate Tube station was rebranded Gareth Southgate station in 2018 [PA Media] In 2018, Southgate Tube station was rebranded Gareth Southgate station for 48 hours, after the England men's football squad he managed finished fourth in the World Cup. More in World In 2023, Bond Street was briefly renamed Burberry Street by the fashion brand to mark London Fashion, which raised £200,000 for the transport company. That led to more than 50 complaints to TfL with some passengers confused by the new temporary signage. Transport for All, a transport advocacy group led by disabled people, warned last year that "thoughtless PR stunts being used to plug holes in TfL funding cannot be at the expense of accessibility and safety for disabled passengers". The group also said that "messing around with station names... stops many disabled people being able to travel confidently". TfL documents state that brand sponsorship on its network can cost up to £7.5m. IFS Cloud's sponsorship of the cable car that links North Greenwich and Custom House in east London is worth £2.1m. The BBC formed a partnership with TfL in January 2022, rebranding Green Park station for 48 hours as Green Planet to promote Sir David Attenborough's five-part series. While brands have previously "taken over" one or more Underground stations for several days, if successful this initiative would be the first time an entire Tube line would get a sponsor, albeit one with just two stations. A TfL spokesperson said: "This new opportunity on the Waterloo & City line is part of our ongoing work to find new ways brands can use our network to engage with their audiences as they travel across the city. "All revenue generated through any brand partnerships with us will be invested into the wider transport network, helping to keep London moving." The line only runs on weekdays between Bank and Waterloo [] The two-stop, three-minute shuttle service is one of only two Tube lines that runs completely underground, the other being the Victoria line. transcript: SPR_COMBO[es]La firma demuestra su legado social y cultural con un homenaje al movimiento "Cool Britannia" “Festival” ha sido ideada por el equipo de la marca y cuenta con producción de Somesuch Pese a estar tradicionalmente asociada a una percepción de sofisticación y a lo clásico, incluso a la realiza y el conservadurismo, Burberry ha sabido dar un giro a su marca a lo largo de los últimos años vinculándose a la cultura popular. La firma da una nueva muestra de ello con su campaña “Festival”, en la que conecta con la temporada de festivales de música, el legado cultural británico y todo el estilo de vida que se ha generado alrededor de estos eventos. Ideada in-house y con producción de Somesuch, la campaña capitaliza la nostalgia y la estética propia de la década de los años 90, en lo que se denominó el movimiento "Cool Britannia", ante un verano marcado a nivel social y cultural por el emblemático festival Glastonbury y la gira de reencuentro de Oasis. La pieza audiovisual principal está dirigida por Kim Gehrig y está protagonizada, entre otros, por los músicos Liam Gallagher y Goldie, o las modelos Alexa Chung y Cara Delevingne. Imágenes de archivo y otras contemporáneas se mezclan al ritmo del tema “Sweet Harmony”, de Liquid, un clásico de la música electrónica. La campaña supone una visión nostálgica, pero auténtica de la temporada de festivales en Reino Unido y el papel que desempeña la moda, concretamente la propuesta de Burberry. La marca evidencia cómo forma parte del tejido social del país y su influencia en la música y la cultura destacando su presencia, no sólo entre los asistentes a los eventos, sino también entre los artistas protagonistas. Es más, según recoge The Stable, Liam Gallagher luce en la campapa su propia parka de Burberry, perteneciente a  la colección primavera-verano 2018 de Christopher Bailey,. La prenda será relanzada a nivel global en una edición limitada a partir de este mes de julio, coincidiendo, precisamente, con el tour de Oasis. "Burberry es una pieza clave del calendario de verano", declaró Daniel Lee, Director Creativo de Burberry, hace unos días, según recoge Variety. "Es a la vez una forma de expresión creativa y un uniforme predilecto para los asistentes a los festivales". Además de la pieza audiovisual principal, la campaña incluye una serie de piezas cortas para redes sociales protagonizadas por los músicos, modelos y artistas que dan vida al mensaje de la marca. Se crea con ello un "collage", una combinación de retratos que reflejan la vida, el ambiente y las emociones de los festivales. La campaña se completa, además de con fotografías que destacan las prendas que pueden ser idóneas para disfrutar de un festival, con contenido que profundiza en el vínculo entre Burberry, la música y la cultural popular británica.

transcript: Hoult follows in Brad Pitt's footsteps by asserting his style on red carpets around the world.By Olivia BatoulJuly 9, 2025HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA - JULY 07: Nicholas Hoult attends the Los Angeles Premiere of Warner Bros. "Superman" at TCL Chinese Theatre at TCL Chinese Theatre on July 07, 2025 in Hollywood, California. (Photo by Matt Winkelmeyer/WireImage)Matt WinkelmeyerSave this storySaveSave this storySave There's competition on the red carpet. Last month, Brad Pitt completed a highly successful fashion marathon while promoting his new project, F1. This month, it's Nicholas Hoult revealing himself as a real model before the eyes of photographers. The British actor first came to public attention at the age of 17 in the series Skins, alongside other future celebrities such as Dev Patel, Daniel Kaluuya, and Kaya Scodelario. Now in his thirties, he stars in Superman—in cinemas July 11—as the great villain Lex Luthor. After a successful 2024, where he starred in three major films—Juror No. 2, Nosferatu, and The Order—the actor is moving on to something even bigger. And he's well aware of the stakes, judging by his clothing choices during the Superman promotional tour, where he's been stealing the show even David Corenswet, who plays Superman himself. Like Pitt, Nicholas Hoult has relied on signature pieces to find his style. The actor is working with Jason Bolden, a stylist to the stars whose male clients include actors Michael B. Jordan and Aaron Pierre, as well as basketball player Stephen Curry. Together, the duo have created a capsule wardrobe, featuring timeless garments with a touch of modernity added through accessorizing or less classic pieces. The actor's fashion marathon began off the red carpet, with a brief (but noteworthy) stopover in New York. NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 30: Nicholas Hoult is seen in Midtown on June 30, 2025 in New York City. (Photo by TheStewartofNY/GC Images)TheStewartofNY His first look? A brown suit by Tom Ford, with an open jacket and beige cotton T-shirt for a semi-formal look. Hoult then appeared in a white tank top covered by a loose-fitting short-sleeved shirt, again in brown. The paparazzi also photographed him in a white wife-beater lightly covered by a gray sweater tied around his torso, accompanied by Céline jeans. NEW YORK, NY - JUNE 30: Nicholas Hoult is seen outside ABC Studios on June 30, 2025 in New York City. (Photo by MediaPunch/Bauer-Griffin/GC Images)MediaPunch/Bauer-Griffin All three looks have something in common: sunglasses and a huge bag. Specifically, the Prada Buckle bag seen with his last two outfits in the Big Apple. Brad Pitt also accessorized well on his F1 promotional tour, as does Jacob Elordi, a veritable collector of handbags. Hoult brought the same signature pieces—this time, coupled with Bottega Veneta's Weekender Getaway bag—during his visit to London. But instead of a white tank top, he wore a Prada outfit, consisting of a brown t-shirt (his new favorite color) with rolled-up sleeves and linen pants, and sunglasses hanging from his belt. He put his exposed biceps away for Superman's London premiere on July 3. Instead, he brought a suit out of his closet: one that was striped and signed Bottega Veneta. The following day, he appeared in a casual look with a Burberry leather jacket from the Winter 2025 collection. LONDON, ENGLAND - JULY 03: Nicholas Hoult attends the "Superman" photocall at Corinthia Hotel London on July 3, 2025 in London, England. (Photo by Alan Chapman/Dave Benett/WireImage)Dave Benett But it was his July 7 look in sunny Los Angeles that confirmed Hoult's status as a stylish man. Black blazer, white shirt, striped tie, glasses (of course) and, above all, black leather pants. We're not talking about the Saint Laurent leather thigh-high boots worn by Alexander Skarsgard at the Cannes Film Festival 2025, of course—but the actor is certainly making a fashion statement nevertheless. English actor Nicholas Hoult attends the Los Angeles premiere of "Superman" at the TCL Chinese Theatre in Hollywood, California, on July 7, 2025. (Photo by VALERIE MACON / AFP) (Photo by VALERIE MACON/AFP via )VALERIE MACON/ The extra touch? His newly dyed hair, first unveiled on the set of Jimmy Kimmel Live at the end of June. Nicholas Hoult left his natural brunette for a platinum blond, which suits him perfectly. The actor has reinvented himself with finesse. And far from an extravagant rebranding, it seems instead that the Brit has (finally) found his style. Original story in VF France.

transcript: In the sports world, some wives and girlfriends are more famous than the athletes they are watching. Fashion brands have noticed. As Wimbledon was underway this week, with players adhering to the tournament's strict all-white dress code, fashion watchers turned their attention to the stands, where personalities like Morgan Riddle, the fashion influencer and girlfriend of the American tennis player Taylor Fritz, brought a slightly bolder look to the Grand Slam. On Monday, the tournament's first day, Ms. Riddle wore a blush pink mini dress by Patou, paired with matching strawberry-adorned mules (a nod to the tournament's well-known strawberry and cream dish) and a red Chanel purse. Her blond hair was tied into a half up, half down style with face-framing tendrils. ''If I dressed incredibly inappropriately for Wimbledon, it would be blasted on social media almost instantly and people would probably troll him for it,'' Ms. Riddle said in an interview, referring to Mr. Fritz. Her wardrobe teems with skirts, dresses, blazers and button-down shirts from brands like Thom Browne, Miu Miu and Burberry -- a far cry from her early days on tour with Mr. Fritz, whom she began a relationship with in 2020. Back then, Ms. Riddle, who did not grow up watching tennis, favored jeans, crop tops and sweatshirts. But as she became more enmeshed in the world of the elite sport, her style evolved to meet its expectations. While Wimbledon does not enforce a dress code for spectators, attendees are encouraged to dress ''smart.'' For men, that typically means tailored separates in muted tones; for women, sundresses and low heels. Ms. Riddle takes it a step further. She is polished from every angle, with every sartorial detail deliberate. That's partly because she is a WAG. The term WAG, an acronym used to refer to the wives and girlfriends of sports stars, gained popularity in the British tabloids in the early 2000s, when it was often attached to the glamorous partners of male soccer players. It reached a fever pitch during the 2006 World Cup, when figures like Victoria Beckham were covered almost as closely as the players themselves were. WAGs have taken on a second life in the American sports world, linked to basketball, football and, more recently, Formula 1 and tennis. Vogue called the summer, packed with the N.B.A. playoffs, the U.S. Open, the Stanley Cup and more, ''WAG season,'' spotlighting figures like Jordyn Woods, an influencer and the girlfriend of the Knicks star Karl-Anthony Towns as well as Kendall Murray, whose partner is Braiden McGregor of the New York Jets. Publications like Glamour published ''get the look'' edits inspired by Taylor Swift's game day outfits as she watched her boyfriend, Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs, play. Fashion brands have taken note. They're not just dressing the athletes anymore, but their partners, too -- for games, appearances and front rows. Reformation leaned in directly, debuting a collection last month designed for tennis spectators with the tagline: ''Those who can't play, watch.'' As interest in the styling choices of WAGs grows, the question becomes: What even is WAG style? Andrew Pokorny, a television producer who worked on ''WAGs Miami,'' a reality series from E! that aired in the mid-2010s, said that while there was not a singular look, most WAGs followed styling codes. For him, it comes down to one thing: projecting wealth. ''The bank account that they have access to, either through marriage or because they've been given beautiful gifts by their partners, does signal access to an elite club,'' Mr. Pokorny said. Bags from Louis Vuitton, Hermès and Fendi are mainstays, as are shoes from Christian Louboutin. But the illusion of wealth matters, too. According to Mr. Pokorny, many women on the show did not want to be seen in the same outfit twice, and they often worked with fast fashion companies like Fashion Nova to maintain the appearance of an endless wardrobe. In 2016, when the show was filming, that led to some flashy choices. But today's most visible WAGs opt for a more understated look. ''Whether it's ostentatious or subverted, it's always intentional,'' Mr. Pokorny said. '' These WAGs know that people are looking at them. It just depends on what's called for at the time.'' The performance of femininity is also crucial to WAG style, said Judy Liao, a professor at the University of Alberta who researches the sociology of sport and gender. In elite men's sports, women have traditionally been sidelined, seen by many as accessories helping to bolster their partner's masculinity rather than as ardent fans or active participants. What a WAG wears, and how she carries herself, can play a key role in that performance, Dr. Liao said. She sees the resurgence of the WAG as partly a pushback to the growing visibility of women's sports and of bodies that fall outside what she calls the Western ideal of femininity and heteronormativity. ''They're too strong, too Black or too queer,'' she said. '' That's still slightly challenging for the North American mainstream audience to really digest.'' ''WAGs really kind of offer the mainstream media this really good material to say, 'We support gender equality because we're showing women in sport,''' Dr. Liao added. '' But it's not the women who are actually playing the sports.'' Athletes themselves have noticed. In April, Daria Saville, the Australian professional tennis player, took to TikTok to express frustration over women tennis players being passed over for brand partnerships in favor of WAGs. Women who, she said, fit the tennis aesthetic that brands were profiting from. There has been, however, a growing trend of brands tapping women athletes for campaigns and endorsement deals. They include the W.N.B.A. player Angel Reese (Good American), the tennis star Coco Gauff (New Balance) and the rugby player Ilona Maher (Maybelline). But WAGs continue to thrive, with some developing larger social media followings than their partners. Sartorially, though, most roads lead back to the athlete. Dressing often becomes a form of fashion diplomacy, echoing the way political spouses represent their partners abroad....

It reached a fever pitch during the 2006 World Cup, when figures like Victoria Beckham were covered almost as closely as the players themselves were. WAGs have taken on a second life in the American sports world, linked to basketball, football and, more recently, Formula 1 and tennis. Vogue called the summer, packed with the N.B.A. playoffs, the U.S. Open, the Stanley Cup and more, ''WAG season,'' spotlighting figures like Jordyn Woods, an influencer and the girlfriend of the Knicks star Karl-Anthony Towns as well as Kendall Murray, whose partner is Braiden McGregor of the New York Jets. Publications like Glamour published ''get the look'' edits inspired by Taylor Swift's game day outfits as she watched her boyfriend, Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs, play. Fashion brands have taken note. They're not just dressing the athletes anymore, but their partners, too -- for games, appearances and front rows. Reformation leaned in directly, debuting a collection last month designed for tennis spectators with the tagline: ''Those who can't play, watch.'' As interest in the styling choices of WAGs grows, the question becomes: What even is WAG style? Andrew Pokorny, a television producer who worked on ''WAGs Miami,'' a reality series from E! that aired in the mid-2010s, said that while there was not a singular look, most WAGs followed styling codes. For him, it comes down to one thing: projecting wealth. ''The bank account that they have access to, either through marriage or because they've been given beautiful gifts by their partners, does signal access to an elite club,'' Mr. Pokorny said. Bags from Louis Vuitton, Hermès and Fendi are mainstays, as are shoes from Christian Louboutin. But the illusion of wealth matters, too. According to Mr. Pokorny, many women on the show did not want to be seen in the same outfit twice, and they often worked with fast fashion companies like Fashion Nova to maintain the appearance of an endless wardrobe. In 2016, when the show was filming, that led to some flashy choices. But today's most visible WAGs opt for a more understated look. ''Whether it's ostentatious or subverted, it's always intentional,'' Mr. Pokorny said. '' These WAGs know that people are looking at them. It just depends on what's called for at the time.'' The performance of femininity is also crucial to WAG style, said Judy Liao, a professor at the University of Alberta who researches the sociology of sport and gender. In elite men's sports, women have traditionally been sidelined, seen by many as accessories helping to bolster their partner's masculinity rather than as ardent fans or active participants. What a WAG wears, and how she carries herself, can play a key role in that performance, Dr. Liao said. She sees the resurgence of the WAG as partly a pushback to the growing visibility of women's sports and of bodies that fall outside what she calls the Western ideal of femininity and heteronormativity. ''They're too strong, too Black or too queer,'' she said. '' That's still slightly challenging for the North American mainstream audience to really digest.'' ''WAGs really kind of offer the mainstream media this really good material to say, 'We support gender equality because we're showing women in sport,''' Dr. Liao added. '' But it's not the women who are actually playing the sports.'' Athletes themselves have noticed. In April, Daria Saville, the Australian professional tennis player, took to TikTok to express frustration over women tennis players being passed over for brand partnerships in favor of WAGs. Women who, she said, fit the tennis aesthetic that brands were profiting from. There has been, however, a growing trend of brands tapping women athletes for campaigns and endorsement deals. They include the W.N.B.A. player Angel Reese (Good American), the tennis star Coco Gauff (New Balance) and the rugby player Ilona Maher (Maybelline). But WAGs continue to thrive, with some developing larger social media followings than their partners. Sartorially, though, most roads lead back to the athlete. Dressing often becomes a form of fashion diplomacy, echoing the way political spouses represent their partners abroad....
reasoning: This is a comprehensive journalistic article about "WAG" (Wives and Girlfriends) fashion at sporting events, published in what appears to be a New York Times style section. While Burberry is mentioned

transcript: They look designer. They feel expensive. They cost less than your morning latte. These secondhand treasures, from cashmere to structured blazers, are the fashion flex no one saw coming. Snobs won't spot the thrift, but they'll definitely clock the taste. Tailored Blazers that Scream Old Money   Photo Credit: Oleg.Ermak88/Depositphotos   The right vintage blazer, especially one with sharp shoulders, quality wool, and a structured fit,  instantly elevates your entire wardrobe. Pair it with jeans or silk pants, and everyone assumes you shop at The Row. Cashmere Sweaters with Whisper Soft Luxury   Photo Credit: Serezniy/Depositphotos   Real cashmere doesn't lie. If you can find a gently worn 100% cashmere sweater in classic tones like oatmeal, navy, or charcoal, you've basically unlocked the secret code to looking expensive on a dime. Retro Leather Jackets with Timeless Swagger   Photo Credit: Y-Boychenko/Depositphotos   Unlike fast fashion knockoffs, vintage leather jackets have that broken in softness and rich patina that only time can create. The kind of cool that even the most fashion jaded can't fake or resist. Denim that Fits Like it was Made for you   Photo Credit: Serezniy/Depositphotos   From '90s Levi's to wide leg Guess jeans, secondhand denim often has a sturdier build and more flattering cut than anything on today's racks. Bonus points if you tailor them, now you're unstoppable. Related: Hair Mistakes Stylists Say Are Aging You Instantly   Designer Scarves that Whisper “I have Taste”   Photo Credit: AntonLozovoy/Depositphotos   Hermès. Burberry. Ferragamo. These silk squares turn up in estate sales and resale apps more than you'd think, and once tied around your neck or bag handle, they radiate silent status. Related: 14 Common Beauty Habits That Are Quietly Damaging Your Skin    Love beauty and skincare products? Here's how to get your FREE Sephora Birthday Gift ! Structured Handbags that don't Shout, they Speak   Photo Credit: Split271992.gmail.com/Depositphotos   A good vintage handbag, think classic shapes, pebbled leather, minimal branding, will get approving nods from snobby fashion insiders who know quality when they see it. Even if it cost you $40. Related: 14 Makeup Mistakes Women Over 40 Still Make Without Realizing   Perfectly Patinated Loafers   Photo Credit: Reversible.com   Genuine Italian leather loafers age like fine wine, gaining character with every step. Scuffed in all the right ways, they look like you inherited them from a stylish grandfather, and that's a very good thing. Related: 5 Mini Skirt Styles That Are Cute Enough to Make You Glow with Confidence   Silk Slip Dresses that Feel like Skin   Photo Credit: IgorVetushko/Depositphotos   When secondhand slips are made from real silk, they flow and cling in all the right ways. Throw on a vintage coat or oversized blazer, and you've just mastered downtown minimalism without trying too hard. Related: 14 Chocolate Brown Outfits So Good, They Might Just Start A Dress Code War   Trench Coats that Make Rain Look Chic   Photo Credit: HoltarenkoAnhelinabo/Depositphotos   A well made trench is never out of style, especially those classic belted versions with epaulettes and crisp collars. Find one in beige, navy, or olive, and suddenly you're the main character in every sidewalk scene. Related: 12 Fashion Tips Women Over 50 Swear By That Actually Work   Chunky Jewelry that Belongs on a Fashion Week Street Style Blog   Photo Credit: AllaSerebrina/Depositphotos   Oversized gold hoops, statement cuffs, and vintage chain necklaces from past decades are fashion gold. They instantly give basic outfits edge and flair, the kind that makes people ask, “Where did you get that?” . Discover practical outfit ideas on my LTK Shop here . Knit Dresses that Hug All the Right Places   Photo Credit: Vk_studio/Depositphotos   Thrifted bodycon knits or midi sweater dresses often come in higher quality than today's mass produced options. Add a belt, knee high boots, and confidence, and boom, you're giving off major It-Girl energy. Related: 14 Cringe Fashion Rules Millennials Still Swear By And Gen Z Hates   Rare Sunglasses that weren't Made for the Masses   Photo Credit: IgorVetushko/Depositphotos   Vintage frames often have unusual shapes, color gradients, or materials you won't find in today's over saturated market. Slip them on, and suddenly you're not following trends, you're setting them. Related: The Game Changing Bra Tricks For Armless And Backless Dresses   Maxi Skirts that Sweep like Couture   Photo Credit: Serezniy/Depositphotos   Whether it's pleated chiffon or structured wool, long secondhand skirts often come with a level of detail and craftsmanship missing from modern versions. And when they move, they move, like drama on a runway. Related: 12 Power Outfits Millennials Swear By For Dates, Jobs, And Drama    Not sure what to wear this season? Discover affordable outfit ideas on my Amazon Storefront ! Button Downs that Mean Business: In a Sexy Way   Photo Credit: Serezniy/Depositphotos   Vintage button downs, especially in crisp cotton or buttery silk, can be styled oversized with rolled sleeves, tucked into tailored pants, or even worn open over a tank. Chic meets effortless. Related: The Outfit Combos Stylish Women Repeat On Loop   Vintage Belts that Tie it All Together   Photo Credit: AndrewLozovyi/Depositphotos   Don't underestimate the power of a bold belt with an ornate buckle or buttery leather. A great vintage belt cinches your waist and your whole outfit, the final touch that pulls everything into fashion snob territory. Related: 5 Black Tie Dresses That Balance Sophistication With Simplicity    The secret to fooling fashion snobs? Confidence and curation. When you pair secondhand pieces with intentional styling, what you're really wearing is good taste, and that never goes out of style. transcript: Sign Up for Gems of Wisdom Anyone who follows the British royal family will have come across the phenomenon that is known as the Kate Effect. Referring to the way in which the Princess of Wales wearing an outfit or piece of jewelry can lead to items selling out online in minutes and even websites crashing, it has been a firm feature of the royal narrative ever since Kate came on the scene. So the announcement this summer that the Princess, along with Prince William, will now have the power to grant Royal Warrants comes with a significant dose of anticipation for the businesses who may be in the running to receive one. She will be the first Princess of Wales to be a grantor in more than 100 years. But, perhaps more pertinently, the first ever to make such endorsements in the online shopping era. “There is a large swath of royal watchers who came to follow the royal family through her and, importantly, shop the brands she wears,” Elizabeth Holmes, author of the New York Times bestseller, HRH: So Many Thoughts on Royal Style, tells T&C. “I think the Princess now being able to grant royal warrants will introduce this honor in a new way to a new generation of royal watchers.” So what exactly is this coveted honor and who is eligible? A Royal Warrant is an official mark of recognition for individuals or companies who have regularly supplied goods or services to the royal household. A business must have supplied a royal for at least five out of the last seven years to qualify and must now also demonstrate a commitment to sustainability. The range of holders covers everything from clothing to food and drink to cleaning products and services, stationery, transport and home and gardening services. Holders can describe themselves as “by appointment” to the royals and display the arms belonging to the royal who selected them on their products and packaging. “A Royal Warrant is seen by many firms as the gold standard of endorsements,” says royal journalist Richard Palmer. “It's an honor but more importantly it's of commercial value…Kate's warrant will be especially sought after.” Shop Kate's Wardrobe Staples McQueen Classic Single-Breasted Suiting Blazer Kiki McDonough Classics Green Amethyst Pear Drop Earrings Mulberry Amberley Clutch Emmy London Rebecca High Heel After Queen Elizabeth's death there was a review of Royal Warrants and for a while King Charles was the only grantor. Queen Camilla has since been appointed a grantor, and she now has 14 warrants while the King has 586. The Palace announced that William and Kate will award their first warrants in a two-step process. Firstly, companies with warrants from the King or Queen can apply to also be endorsed by William or Kate. Those applications are open now and the selections will be announced next spring. Next year, applications will be open to other companies. So who might Kate choose? Intriguingly, while there is no requirement for warrant-holders to be British-owned or UK-based, William's private secretary made it clear that this is the route the couple plan to take. “Their Royal Highnesses are delighted to be able to recognise and celebrate British industry, creativity and skills through the granting of Warrants,” Ian Patrick said. Two favorite clothing brands of Kate's, Burberry and Barbour, already hold warrants from the King. She could also potentially add her endorsement to milliner Philip Treacy, who has a warrant from the Queen. In new appointments, several experts have suggested that her go-to designers Catherine Walker and Jenny Packham are at the top of the list of contenders. “Key factors are likely to include a brand's history and heritage, its role in British culture and contributions to the community, as well as its corporate governance and business practices,” Susan Kelley, founder of website What Kate Wore, tells T&C. Kelley cites labels including “Catherine Walker, Erdem, Beulah London, Jenny Packham, and perhaps a childrenswear brand like Trotters London,” as contenders. “Brora, a clothing brand specializing in cashmere manufactured using heritage textile mills in Scotland, seems a very good candidate for recognition, as do Campbell's of Beauly and Dubarry of Ireland,” she says. “I do wonder if Kate, who has mastered the art of high-low dressing, will include more affordable brands in her royal warrant selection,” says Elizabeth Holmes. “Her high street choices have made her seem accessible in a novel way, and I'm certain the impact on those brands would be sizable should she choose to recognize them.” Shop Kate's Wardrobe Staples Jenny Packham Georgia Embellished Sequined Tulle Gown Monica Vinader Siren Gemstone Wire Earrings LK Bennett Dora Green Suede Envelope Clutch Penelope Chilvers Tassel Knee High Boot Royal fashion expert Christine Ross also points out that the impact of a warrant could be more measurable if Kate chooses smaller or more affordable brands. “A brand's accessibility in both price and international delivery would be key to their Royal Warrant leading to success,” she adds. Kate's influence on the British fashion industry is so often highlighted, with figures such as her boosting it by an estimated £1 billion annually repeatedly cited. But there is a point to be made about to what extent she will want to highlight fashion with her first tranche of appointments. “The royal warrants come at an interesting time in the broader royal fashion conversation,” Elizabeth Holmes says. “So much has been made about whether or not to discuss the Princess's wardrobe, and where she wants the focus to be. That sentiment seems to have been walked back, and we've seen a number of fashion-focused moments this year, but it will be interesting to see the types of warrants she grants, and what share of those are clothing and accessories versus other categories.” “I suspect their first few Royal Warrants will be conservatively chosen,” says Christine Ross....

Scottish cashmere specialist Brora, Campbell's of Beauly and Dubarry of Ireland also feature among potential recipients. The Princess's influence on British fashion remains substantial, with some estimations suggesting she has boosted the industry by around £1billion during her time in the Royal Family. "I do wonder if Kate, who has mastered the art of high-low dressing, will include more affordable brands in her royal warrant selection," Holmes added. Royal fashion expert Christine Ross noted that smaller or more affordable brands could see measurable impact. "A brand's accessibility in both price and international delivery would be key to their Royal Warrant leading to success," she claimed. The global reach of online shopping amplifies the commercial benefits significantly. "Internet and online shopping has made it so that the customer base for any given business is suddenly global," Holmes said. "There is something quite special in being able to buy something for yourself or give it as a gift and say, 'This is Kate approved.'" Applications are now open for businesses already holding warrants from the King or Queen to seek endorsement from the Princess of Wales or Prince William. The Palace announced the couple will award their first warrants through a two-stage process. Current warrant holders can apply immediately, with selections to be announced next spring. Applications will open to other companies next year. "Their Royal Highnesses are delighted to be able to recognise and celebrate British industry, creativity and skills through the granting of Warrants," Ian Patrick, William's private secretary, said. The focus will be on British-owned or UK-based businesses. A Royal Warrant serves as an official mark of recognition for companies that have regularly supplied goods or services to the royal household. Businesses must have supplied a royal for at least five of the past seven years and demonstrate sustainability commitments to qualify. "A Royal Warrant is seen by many firms as the gold standard of endorsements," royal journalist Richard Palmer said. "It's an honour, but more importantly, it's of commercial value…Kate's warrant will be especially sought after."

transcript: SPR_COMBO[it]A quasi 30 anni dal loro esordio, gli Oasis sono tornati a dominare la scena – non solo musicale, ma anche della cultura di branding. Con il reunion tour finalmente in corso, il capitale culturale della band sembra più attuale che mai: streetwear, moda premium, retail pop-up e attivazioni ironiche sfruttano il ritorno di Liam e Noel per connettersi con una community transgenerazionale, attraverso nostalgia, identità e fandom. A guidare l'ondata è Adidas Originals , che a giugno ha lanciato una collaborazione ad alto profilo con la band. Anticipata sui social e svelata in TV su Channel 4, la campagna è accompagnata da Live Forever (1994), con un mix di filmati d'archivio e nuove clip dei fratelli Gallagher. In evidenza, i prodotti-guida della collezione: tute, maglie raglan, bucket hat e coach jacket. Non si tratta solo di merchandising, ma di storytelling condiviso. Adidas fa parte del look Oasis fin dai loro albori, e il claim “Original Forever” riscrive quella narrativa per le nuove generazioni. Anche Levi's ha realizzato una capsule di T-shirt in edizione limitata, ma la Oasis Mania va oltre lo streetwear e il denim. Burberry ha lanciato una campagna con Liam Gallagher e i suoi figli Lennon, Gene e Molly, insieme a volti noti come Goldie, Cara Delevingne e Alexa Chung, con uno styling che richiama l'era d'oro Burberry degli anni '90., mentre Stone Island ha scelto Liam come volto della campagna autunnale. Non si tratta solo di endorsement: l'artista è il concept. Oltre all'impatto culturale, c'è quello di business: secondo Barclays , i fan UK degli Oasis spenderanno oltre 1 miliardo di sterline tra biglietti, viaggi e merchandising – più di quanto registrato dai fan di Taylor Swift in occasione dell'Eras Tour, con sole 2 date in più. Nel cuore di Londra, il temporary store Oasis in Carnaby Street è già meta di pellegrinaggio per fan e curiosi. T-shirt, hoodie, bucket hat, poster e vinili in edizione limitata – inclusa la collezione Adidas Originals x Oasis – rendono il punto vendita un'esperienza immersiva che unisce musica e moda. Anche i retailer più mainstream si inseriscono nel trend. Primark ha celebrato la data di apertura del tour a Manchester con una campagna social che chiedeva ai fan di scegliere il loro Gallagher preferito, e un attivazione sul punto vendita con die ingressi separati: Liam e Noel. Lidl , invece, giocando sull'ironi, ha lanciato  Lidl by Lidl, una giacca da concerto in edizione limitata, presentata oltre che sul proprio sito web su un murale nei pressi dell'Etihad Stadium. Prezzo: £30. Caratteristiche: tasche refrigeranti, apribottiglie. Ovviamente esaurita, ma i fan possono approfittare del  prossimo drop: il Lidl  by Lidl bucket hat. Il tutto con finalità benefica a favore dell'NSPCC. Sul fronte digitale, abbiamo già segnalato come  Warner Music abbia attivato uno shop ufficiale con merch esclusivo su Amazon , permettendo ai fan di tutto il mondo di acquistare al di là delle date del tour o delle attivazioni locali. Un chiaro segnale: il fandom va oltre il live, e si costruisce anche attraverso una distribuzione scalabile. Sullo sfondo, parka e bucket hat sono l'ossessione della stagione, che qualche professionista dell'abbigliamento definisce ha già definito la “Wonderwall Summer”. L'Oasis Mania non è solo un ritorno nostalgico. È un caso di piattaforma culturale attiva : tra collaborazioni fashion, campagne streetwear, progetti retail e attivazioni ironiche, i Gallagher rimangono tra i pochi artisti capaci di connettere generazioni e sottoculture. E in un momento in cui i brand cercano autenticità, emozione e narrazione, Oasis è ancora una colonna sonora che fa vendere.

transcript: Hey yall, Been out the game a while & looking at prices these days I figured aside from trying out testers I could perhaps get some advice from some more seasoned folks (pardon the pun). Long story short, the descriptions just do not compute for me. This isn't just with cologne either, but also weed. When someone describes something as nutty or woody, I do not get that at all. I don't smell almond or vanilla, but I do smell the baby powered smell I've seen people use to describe it. So idk. Hoping to just kind of use examples of the vibes I like and see if maybe someone can point me in the right direction. I've used AI to the best of my ability with this, but it refuses to give me actual recommendations outside ones I've already tried (and told it about) and the same handful. Also, the relevant factors coming into play outside of preference are: - I'm 35; - I work in the legal field; and - I'm a cigarette smoker So, when I was young my go-to was Abercrombie fierce, then graduating to aqua De Gio as one did from 2005-2011, perhaps they still do idk lol. Those are too “fresh” and “young” to me tho nowadays. I wore guilty by Gucci & Gucci by Gucci in the past and would fluctuate between really liking one and not the other. My favorite female scent is D&G Light Blue, but the male version didn't really do it for me. I bought the Yves Saint Laurent [here](https://www.macys.com/shop/product/yves-saint-laurent-mens-2-pc.-y-myslf-eau-de-parfum-gift-set?ID=19213960&cm_mmc=SMS-_-MAPP_pdpshare-_-n-_-n”) And while I like them both, I want something a tad “heavier”. I also bought a tester of Tom Ford's Fucking Fabulous and I really enjoy it but the “baby powder” smell that is present bugs me enough to not wanna fork over the money for a full bottle. But I very much enjoy the “complexity” or “layers” I guess you'd say? And despite being a sweeter smell it endures cigarettes well. Sauvage is good until it isn't. No disrespect but I get axe body spray vibes from it but the grown up version. Bleu is awesome but everyone I know has it. My ex got me a jimmy choo one that I can't recall the exact name of that was so-so but didn't really blow my hair back. Would love you feedback on what u think I should look into more. The ones I've been considering are: - Le Male by SPG - Afternoon Swim (concern is lasting power) - Jazz Club by MM - Valentino Uomo Born in Roma -  Burberry Weekend -  Terre d'Hermès - Tom Ford Oud Wood And then based on the descriptions I feel like I prob won't like spice bomb but who knows. Any and all help is greatly appreciated!

transcript: ASTRO's Cha Eun-Woo will commence his services on July 28. Before the services, he organized a fun meet and greet with his fans in Seoul. Cha Eun Woo delivers a surprise performance K-Pop boyband ASTRO member Cha Eun-Woo has recently sent his fans into a frenzy following his surprise performance. The singer and actor surprised his fans with an exciting performance on the upbeat track from the animated film KPop Demon Hunters, Soda Pop, creating a buzz among the fans. Several videos from his performance are going viral on social media. True Beauty fame actor recently organised a fan meeting event, The Royal, in Seoul ahead of mandatory military enlistment. Story continues below During the event, Eun-Woo delighted his fans with the viral Saja Boys song Soda Pop. For his performance, the singer wore a royal-inspired outfit, channelling a prince-like look that matched the event's regal theme. He brought charm and vibrant energy to the stage with ease. The singer took to his social media to share the behind-the-scenes of the event. He penned in the caption, “I was Happy.” The singer's latest performance came as he prepares for his upcoming mandatory military enlistment. He will commence his services on July 28. For the unversed, Cha Eun-Woo made his solo debut in February 2024 with his EP Entity, featuring the lead single Stay. Meanwhile, Eun-Woo's credits also include acting, and he has delivered stellar performances in K-dramas like True Beauty, Island, and Sweet Revenge, among others. Apart from his work in music and acting, Eun-Woo has made a significant impact in the fashion industry. He represents major global brands like Calvin Klein, Dior, and Burberry as a brand ambassador. His rising influence in fashion has gained him wide recognition, including a place on Elle Thailand's list of 30 Most Inspiring People.
